nars.util.data.id

Class Identifier<E extends Identifier>

  • java.lang.Object
    • nars.util.data.id.Identifier<E>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    UTF8Identifier

    public abstract class Identifier<E extends Identifier>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable, java.io.Serializable
    Generic abstract identifier for symbols, tags, and other identifiables. It is responsible for maintaining efficient time and space equality, lexicographic ordering, and hashing of representations of tokens / symbols / identifiers. can generate the following representations: --pretty String output ( default behavior of .toString() ) --compact String output (ex: does not include spaces for readability, newlines, etc.) --internal byte[] - most compact and does not need to be human readable reducing the size of internal representations does not only save memory but it is faster to compare and hash, and may hash with better entropy.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • toUtf8

        public static byte[] toUtf8(char[] str)

      • charsFromWriter

        public char[] charsFromWriter(boolean pretty)
        produces the character array by invoking the append() method that certain subclasses use to form their data lazily/dynamically. this is guaranteed to work for all but may not be the most efficient - subclasses are free to provide more efficient ones for their cases.
        Parameters:
        pretty - - whether to include spaces and other whitespace-like formatting
        Returns:
        character array which may need trimmed for trailing zero '\0' characters

      • charsByName

        public char[] charsByName()
        use this if the input is constant and already known (static). avoids calling the writer and just decodes the utf8 representation directly this is why it does not use the 'pretty' parameter because it would have no effect

      • chars

        public char[] chars(boolean pretty)
        use this when this class must generate an output by a writer this is the default general implementation.
